handDesc.p: Halantas. Final M is derived from the shape of a classical ma with an upward extension that bends right and then up again, but is now stylised into a circle with a tail on top that bends right and then up. The circle part is much like an anusvāra. E.g. l3 °litānāM. Final N is likewise based on na, but has only a horseshoe shape at the bottom, with the upward tail bending right, up, then right again. E.g. l10 māsāN. Final T is formed in the same way. A clear example is l17 avarddhayaT; cchinaT in l15 is unclear at the top and may be cchinata, just like harata for haraT earlier in the same line.
Original punctuation marks are long, straight and plain verticals. This sign is doubled after l27 ca. The one after l14-15 āharata is unclear and may in fact consist of three short verticals.

Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is a fairly large circle well above the headline, atop or to the right of the consonant to which it belongs, occasionally atop the next character, probably only when displaced by a descender, e.g. the first anusvāra of l10 saptatriṁśataṁ is above śa, because stra in the previous line prevents it from being closer to tri. Occasionally it is also lowered to or below headline height, e.g. l1 Ekānnaviṁśatin, where jo and vi in the previous line (themselves pushed downward by descenders further above) prevent its regular placement. Rare jha occurs (as a subscript consonant) in l26 jhaṭiti. Upadhmānīya occurs before l45 parantapaḥ. Initial Ī occurs in line 52, but in the scanned photo it cannot be made out at all.

app.note: The first three characters of this word are closely spaced, and the vowel of hā is added on top of the consonant rather than as an extension of the top to the right. Some level of correction is probably involved here. Possibly, svāmihāsena or svāmahāsena was first engraved and then corrected to the expected text; or, in a more simple scenarion, the ā of hā was omitted and added later on.
Pre-modern correction may be present here. The superfluous ā mātrās may have been deleted, and it is also possible that tadānujo was first engraved and then corrected into the expected text.
Possibly a typo in Sankaranarayanan's edition.
The scanned photo is not clear enough for me to tell whether the expected ā is present, but I suspect a typo in Sankaranarayanan's edition.
Most of this line is unclear to wholly illegible in the scanned photo; but Sankaranarayanan only marks naṁdaya as unclear.

Based on the scanned photo, I am not entirely sure this is corrected text. Sankaranarayanan in a footnote anchored after ca|| at the beginning of this line says, These 7 letters are engraved on an erasure. I see no trace of erasure at that point, nor any clear way of identifying which 7 letters the note may refer to. However, he also prints the seven characters of this locus in square brackets (normally signifying unclear). These characters are quite clearly legible, but seem to be surrounded with a fair amount of noise and to have less neat lines. I thus assume that Sankaranarayanan's note refers to this locus, and that he was in a position to confidently discern vestiges of deleted writing underneath these.
The double l is probably a typo in Sankaranarayanan's edition, and the reason he emends is only the anusvāra.
The scribe has omitted the two circles that form the lower part of I.

My reading/restoration of this pāda is beyond tentative and very likely incorrect. I am, however, wholly certain that Sankaranarayanan's restoration is impossible, and fairly confident that its purport ought to be that Vijayāditya died (see also the commentary). An examination of the original or a good estampage may be very helpful here. The subscript consonant below n is squarish in shape and below it there is a clear stroke for subscript r that may continue in a curl to signify r̥. (There is definitely no i atop this conjunct, and Sankaranarayanan's reading nkri may be a typo for nkr̥.) The next character is definitely not ta, but a conjunct consisting of two consonants with either an upward ā or a short repha on top of it. Its principal consonant, on its own, could be c, j, ḍ, d, p, m, or ṣ, but with the conspicuous notch in the upper outline of the largely oval subscript component, the two consonants together are most likely to be cch, or possibly jñ. The vestiges of the last three characters in the line are too indistinct to identify in the scanned photo. Aside from my tentative restoration, the first word of the pāda could conceivably be prajñā, śraddhā, pṛṣṭhā, etc., but I cannot think of a meaningful restoration involving any other readings. The meaning I propose could be achieved through simpler words such as prāptavān antya-satkr̥tim. This is, however, counterindicated by the vestiges, especially by the lack of an ā on the first conjunct and the presence of a conspicuous ā or repha on the second. Conversely, the use of the rare verbal form prārcchat seems to be in line with the composer’s style. On a final note, premodern correction may well have taken place at this locus. This would explain why the characters are particularly unclear. The pre-correction text may have been slightly shorter, compelling the scribe to make his post-correction text narrower and use ā mātrās that extent upward (rather than right and down) from the heads of consonants (in kāmā in the previous pāda and possibly in the second unclear conjunct within the lemma).

Although Sankaranarayanan prints a single dot for this lacuna, in a footnote he proposes to restore two characters into it, which definitely cannot fit here. I believe I can make out vestiges of a subscript r and perhaps an ī squeezed in below nta in the previous line, and assume that the lady's name was śrī-mahādevī rather than plain mahādevī. Nonetheless, restoring tasyai ca (which may have been Sankaranarayanan's intent) is likewise possible, as is tasyaiva (for tasyā eva).

Sankaranarayanan prints only śa as unclear, but only tai is discernible in the scanned photo. He assumes that this is the name of a Śiva temple connected to Tailāmbā. I accept the reading on his authority, but unless vestiges of śa can indeed be made out in the original, I believe that taila-pūrvva-kṣetram is a more likely restoration, meaning a field that was already in the possession of the family of Tailāmbā.

The final a is probably a typo in Sankaranarayanan's edition, since in his discussion he mentions the Devula Ceṟuvvu (sic) tank. Sankaranarayanan further notes that this term is engraved over an erasure. This is not obvious in the scanned photo, but the characters vulaceṟu are surrounded by plenty of noise, including a quite definite stroke between ce and ṟu.

div.head: Plates
div.p: Greetings! Satyāśraya Vallabhendra Pulakeśin II was fit to adorn the lineage of the majestic Caḷukyas—who are of the Mānavya gotra which is praised by the entire world, who are sons of Hārīti, who attained kingship by the grace of Kauśikī’s boon,Or, alternatively, by the grace of Kauśikī’s bridegroom, i.e. Śiva. In spite of its slight awkwardness, I prefer the former interpretation because the Bādāmi Cālukyas refer to themselves as nourished saṁvardhita by Kauśikī. who are protected by the band of Mothers, who were deliberately appointed to kingship by Lord Mahāsena, to whom the realms of adversaries instantaneously submit at the mere sight of the superior Boar emblem they have acquired by the grace of the divine Nārāyaṇa, and whose bodies have been hallowed through washing in the purificatory ablutions avabhr̥tha of the Aśvamedha sacrifice. His brother Kubja Viṣṇuvardhana reigned for eighteen years. His son Jayasiṁha I, for thirty-three. His younger brother Indrarāja’s son Viṣṇuvardhana II, for nine. His son Maṅgi Yuvarāja, for twenty-five. His son Jayasiṁha II, for thirteen. His younger brother Kokkili, for six months. His elder brother Viṣṇurāja Viṣṇuvardhana III, for thirty-seven. His son Vijayāditya I, for nineteen. His son Viṣṇurāja Viṣṇuvardhana IV, for thirty-six years. His son Vijayāditya II, for forty. His son Kali Viṣanuṇuvardhana V, for a year and a half. His firstborn progeny, the one who—

forcibly seized, in order to donate it, the silver and other goods of the Kāliṅgas and the Gaṅgas, the elephants and other goods of the Lords of Kośala, and the gold and other goods of the Pāṇdyas and the Pallavas;
pressed the Gaṅgas up to the Gaṅga peak, struck off the head of Maṅgi, defeated Kr̥ṣṇa in battle—who would be capable of recounting his brave deeds?
—that Vijayāditya III strengthened the land of Veṅgī year after year for forty-four years.
Then, after two Jayasiṁhas and likewise five Viṣṇuvardhanas, Kokkili along with Maṅgi, and three Vijayādityas had thus passed—
that Vijayāditya’s III brother was King bhūpati Vikramāditya who conquered the entire surface of the earth by his valour vikrama. His firstborn son—
ascended the throne, pulverised his foes, held the earth in his fetters, gladdened his subjects, displayed his glory, duly worshipped Brahmins, honoured the worthy, bore garlands of virtue;

the one who, wrathfully mounting the heavy shoulder of his excellent elephant the raging Ādityaprasāda, with the arrows released from his bow at once dispersed—just as the sun ascending Mount Sunrise disperses the darkness with its rays—the dastardly Karṇāṭas stationed on the bank of the Godā, who had occupied the entire earth, and the Lāṭakas with their smartly prancing horses—

that shelter of the entire world sarva-lokāśraya, His Majesty Viṣṇuvardhana Cālukya-Bhīma I, Supreme Lord parameśvara of Emperors mahārājādhirāja and supreme devotee of Maheśvara, commands all householders kuṭumbin—including foremost the territorial overseers rāṣṭrakūṭa—who reside in Varavara district viṣaya as follows:
The foremost vassal sāmanta Sarvarāja of renowned valour had a daughter named Tailāmbā, as the Himalaya had the daughter Umā.
Yuddhamalla of the boar ensign, son of the vassal prince named His Highness Baladakayya, married her as Śambhu married Umā.

Their resplendent daughter Śrī-Mahādevī was slender but bent with the weight of her plump and firm breasts; here eyes were bright and wide, her fingers, toes, soles and palms resembled tender aśoka sprigs, her navel was recessed and her hipsThe word kṣitā or kṣita is not known from other sources, but must mean hips or buttocks here. heavy, her lips were like a ripe bimba fruit, and her complexion was like heated gold.

She was married byThe words describing Śrī-Mahādevī in stanzas 8-9 are all in the accusative, but there is no verb of which she is the object. See the commentary for the background of my interpretation. the son of Niravadya Dhavala, grandson of the vassal sāmanta lord His Highness Pāṇḍarāṅga and one whose head was wrapped in the impeccable turban duly inherited in the celebrated lineage of castellans kaṭaka-rāja,
and who—

appeared like Manu in his considerate speech, like Hari in his majesty with Lakṣmī, like Death in his valour, like Love in his physical beauty, like Guru Br̥haspati in his intellect, like a wish-fulfilling tree in his generosity;
moreover,

the valour of this Vijayāditya was indomitable, his figure bright as the sun, his mind innately excellent, his truthfulness constant, his banner of victory unbroken, his reputation brilliant like tufts of kāśa grass, his wealth great, his demeanour thoughtfully pleasant, his generosity lauded by the needy, his wisdom esteemed by the wise on earth.

His Highness the above Vijayāditya, truthful of speech and a scorcher of foes, after achieving the three human objectives duty dharma, pleasure kāma and wealth artha, attained the last rites i.e. died.

To that Śrī-Mahādevī, we, Cālukya-Bhīma,See the commentary for my understanding of this elliptical passage. fondly recalling the previous service done by her husband, have granted the village named Moga with an exemption from all taxes, in order to proclaim our gratitude.

Its boundaries are as follows. To the east, the escarpment In his discussion, Sankaranarayanan translates taṭī as tank. This may be some regional usage of the word that I am not aware of, but normally taṭī would mean a bank not necessarily of a watercourse. named Puliyeṟu. To the southeast, the Mūṇṭha-Rāvula pond guṇṭha. To the south, the field of the Ceṁbaṟu-Narendreśvara temple. To the southwest, the field of the Taila-Śarva temple. My translation is based on Sankaranarayanan’s reading, but see the apparatus to line 50 for my doubts concerning this. To the west, the Devula reservoir ceṟuvu. To the northwest, the western tank taṭāka of the village Carmaṇḍi. To the north, Peddapūṇḍi-cariya. According to Sankaranarayanan, this means a precipice or valley belonging to Peddapūṇḍi village. To the northeast, Reṇṭhamrākulu. According to Sankaranarayanan, this means some two trees (?). Let no-one pose an obstacle to her enjoyment of her rights over it. Moreover,
A donor of land rejoices in heaven for sixty millennia, while a seizer of granted land and a condoner of such seizure shall reside in hell for just as many.

The executor ājñapti of this grant is the chamberlain kaḍeya-rājaThe term kaḍeya-rāja, equivalent to kaḍa-eṟeya and kaṭaka-rāja, is normally understood to mean a chief officer of the royal camp (cf. 183-185 and kaṭaka-rāja). However, as it seems to denote a very high hereditary office in the Cālukyan court, I believe it had in this case no direct association with any army camps. himself. This grant was composed racita by Bhaṭṭa Vāmana. Written likhita by Koṇḍācārya.

div.head: Plates
div.p: qui, rapporta, par la force, l’argent des Kāliṁga et des Gaṁga, etc., les éléphants des Kośala, etc., maître de l’or des Pāṇḍya et des Pallava , etc., dans le but de les donner ;

contraignit les Gaṁga à monter sur le Gaṁgakūṭa, coupa la tête de Maṁgi,Il est aussi question de ce personnage dans les insc. nos 32, str.5 ; 37, str. 10, 41. vainquit au combat Kr̥ṣṇa, - qui pourrait décrire les exploits que produisit sa fougue?-
Lui, Vijayāditya, fit prospérer à chaque saison le royaume de Veṅgī, pendant quarante-quatre années.
Lorsque les deux Jayasiṁha, les cinq Viṣṇuvardhana avec Maṁgi, Kokkili, les trois Vijayāditya, s’en furent allés,
le fils aîné du roi Vikramāditya, dont la vaillance avait conquis toute la surface de la terre, le frère de ce dernier Vijayāditya.

Il s’assit sur le trône, tourmenta ses ennemis, veilla sur la terre, fit la joie de ses sujets, étendit sa gloire vertueuse, honora les deux-fois-nés, respecta les saints hommes, porta des guirlandes de vertus.

Monté sur les épaules d’un excellent maître éléphant ivre de fureur, faveur octroyée par Aditya,Le nom Aditya désigne à la fois le dieu et son oncle Vijayāditya qui lui a légué le royaume. dans sa colère, des flèches décochées de son arc - tel le soleil parvenu Mont du Levant, chasse la nuit en dardant les rayons de la lumière matinale, il délogea les Karṇaṭa qui, tenant la terre entière, occupaient les rives de la Godāvarī, ainsi que, soudainement, les Laṭaka mécréants, dont les chevaux dansaient avec adresse.

Lui, refuge du monde entier, l’illustre Viṣṇuvardhana Cālukya Bhīma, roi suprême des grands rois, seigneur suprême, dévôt de Māheśvara, ordonne ceci aux chefs de familles, habitant le rāṣṭra de Varavara, rāṣṭrakūṭa en tête :
Ce roi universel, éminent feudataire, au tejas renommé, telle Umā née d’Himalaya, avait une fille nommée Tailāmbā.

Le fils du seigneur des feudataires, - illustre, nommé Baladakayya -, l’épousa, comme Śaṁbhu, Yuddhamalla, porteur de la marque du sanglier ;La strophe 7 poursuit peut-être la comparaison diagrammatique entre la lignée divine śivaïte et la lignée du héros. La relation bimba-pratibimba est fondée sur l’analogie entre la relation filiale de Tailāṁbā et Sarvarāja et celle d’Umā et Himālaya. La comparaison de Baladakayya à Śaṁbhu incite à penser que cette figure se poursuit sur la strophe 7 : la relation conjugale de ce dernier et Tailāṁbā correspondant à celle de Śiva et Umā. Mais le composé sūkara-lāṁchanaḥ, « porteur de la marque du sanglier », dans le pāda d, ne peut désigner que Viṣṇu, lui aussi qualifié souvent de « Śaṁbhu ». Cette expression est une allusion au sceau des Cālukya de Veṅgī.
sa fille fut l’illustre Mahādevī, aux resplendissants yeux en amande, dont la peau des doigts des mains et des pieds étaient un massif de bourgeons d’aśoka,
qui ployait sous le poids de ses seins charnus et proéminents, au nombril profond, à la démarche grave, aux lèvres couleur du bimba mûr, menue, éclatante comme l’or en fusion, resplendissante.
Le seigneur des feudataires, l’illustre Pāṇḍarāṁga, eut un descendant exempt de blâme et splendide, dont le front s’ornait du bandeau irréprochable hérité du lignage célèbre des kaṭakarāja ;
et,

il ressemble à Manu par ses paroles réfléchies, à Hari par sa Fortune, à Kr̥tānta par sa vaillance, à Smara par sa beauté, par son intelligence, au guru,Br̥haspati. par sa libéralité à l’arbre à vœux .
Et,

Il possédait une vaillance invincible, une beauté resplendissante, un esprit naturellement éminent, toujours sincère, exempt de méchanceté, il possédait une gloire à la forme éclatante telle un dais de ses victoires, la puissance, une conduite charmante fondée sur une abondante réflexion, lui dont les dons étaient loués par les nécessiteux, doué d’une sagesse estimée par les sages sur terre, lui Vijayāditya.

L’illustre Vijayāditya, aux paroles sincères, destructeur des ennemis, atteignit la réalisation du dharma, du kāma et de l’artha,Il manque cinq syllabes. On attend, après l’énumération des trois buts, l’évocation du quatrième but, mokṣa. Le fait que le roi fasse un don de village à Mahādevī corrobore l’hypothèse que ce personnage soit mort.

Vijayāditya, qui éprouvait de la reconnaissance au souvenir des services rendus par l’époux de celle-ci, donne à cette Mahādevī le village nommé Moga, exempté de toute taxe, à l’occasion d’une annonce portée à la connaissance de tous,

Les limites de ce dernier sont : à l’est le rivage nommé Puliyeṟu, au sud-est l’étang de Muṇṭha-Rāvula, au sud le terrain de Narendreśvara, Ceṁbaṟu, au sud-ouest tout le terrain de Taila, à l’ouest Devulaceṟuva, au nord-ouest un étang à l’ouest Carmmaṇḍi , au nord Peddapūṇḍi-Cariya, au nord-est Ṟeṇṭhamrākulu. Aucune charge ne doit lui être imposée. Ainsi Vyāsa a-t-il dit :
le donateur d’une terre se réjouit pendant soixante mille années dans le ciel ; celui qui abroge cette donation ou l’approuve réside tout aussi longtemps en enfer.
L’exécuteur de ce don est précisément le kaḍeyarāja. Cet édit a été composé par Bhaṭṭavāmana et gravé par Koṇḍacārya.
Sankaranarayanan gives the metre of stanza 4 as indravaṁśā, in which case the first quarter should begin with a short syllable.
For verse 10, Sankaranarayanan cites the parallel niravadya-dhavalaḥ kaṭakarāja-paṭṭa-śobhita-talaṭaḥ (sic, probably lalāṭaḥ) from CalE47, line 45.

I assume (with Sankaranarayanan) that Vijayāditya, introduced in stanza 10 as the son of Niravadya Dhavala and grandson of Pāṇḍarāṅga, married the lady Śrī-Mahādevī (father: Yuddhamalla; paternal grandfather: Baladakayya; mother: Tailāmbā; maternal grandfather: Sarvarāja). This rests on the assumption that a brief bit of connecting prose such as tāṁ paryanayat has been omitted after stanza 9, or that tām … avoḍha from stanza 7 must be understood at this point too. I further assume (again with Sankaranarayanan) that Vijayāditya has died and that the donor is the king, who rewards Vijayāditya’s widow for her husband’s service. To arrive at this, we need to emend santuṣṭaḥ in line 47 to an instrumental and supply a name or pronoun to which it stands in apposition (e.g. asmābhiḥ … santuṣṭaiḥ or cālukya-bhīmena … santuṣṭena). I further believe (unlike Sankaranarayanan), that Vijayāditya’s death must have been mentioned in the problematic stanza 13 (for which see the apparatus to line 45). Were this not the case, the flow of the text would have too many gaps and the implication would be that Vijayāditya is the donor. This alternative possibility cannot be rejected out of hand. It would first require us to understand Śrī-Mahādevī and Tailāmbā to be the same person (whose father is Sarvarāja), and second, to emend dattaḥ in line 48 to an active verb, e.g. dattavān. These assumptions are in themselves no less plausible than those required for the scenario first proposed. Moreover, the fact that the ājñapti is stated to be the kaḍeya-rāja "himself" (eva), without a name, seems to imply that it is the kaḍeya-rāja named above, viz. Vijayāditya. However, I believe that if the donor were not the king himself, then this would be stated more explicitly in the text and the king’s consent would also be mentioned. The executor may then have been, as I assume with Sankaranarayanan, a son or other heir of Vijayāditya.

The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on a collation of Sankaranarayanan's text with his photos.The photos, as printed, are not very clear and scanning has not improved them. Many details should ideally be checked against a better facsimile. Sankaranarayanan's edition has many typographic mistakes; only major ones are shown in the apparatus here and others are silently assumed to have been correctly read by Sankaranarayanan and misprinted in his text.
